name: sfchronicle
text: With the pandemic surging across the country, more and more communities are keeping watch for the virus in wastewater. https://t.co/ozA7DbyCfy

name: sfchronicle
text:
.@SanJoseStateFB coach Alonzo Carter hosts a biweekly Zoom call that routinely draws hundreds of Black coaches from around the country to network, discuss systemic racism and progression in their sport.

@annkillion has more: https://t.co/HuvzdC6DN7

name: sfchronicle
text:
The coronavirus has now infected more than 40,000 people in the Bay Area, a region once credited with taking aggressive, early action to stem the spread of the virus. As of Friday, there were 40,068 total cases.

See the latest data on our Virus Tracker: https://t.co/L8LLxjvFF5

name: sfchronicle
text: “The leaderboards are going to look weird. ...  You can expect really weird teams in the playoffs as well. It takes only a strong 60-game stretch to get in.” https://t.co/6F6MuOOPkM

name: sfchronicle
text: "At least we can take heart that it's true, for now at least, that if you live in San Francisco and test positive, there's still a paycheck for you." https://t.co/p29gvrJ7UE

name: sfchronicle
text: Marin County will decide whether to fine people who violate shelter-in-place health orders, officials said. The Board of Supervisors will take up the issue, including fines for businesses that are not supposed to be open, group gatherings and parties. https://t.co/l8gvzRrVsD

name: sfchronicle
text:
Embattled East Bay priest Varghese “George” Alengadan has been charged with sexual battery against a woman from his time as pastor of St. Joseph Basilica in Alameda.

https://t.co/bH1PdZd06X

name: sfchronicle
text: Scientists hope that human excrement can help guide health policy today, telling them where the novel coronavirus emerges, what areas should receive medical supplies or be locked down, and when it may be safe to reopen communities. https://t.co/dNZjEUOLP4

name: sfchronicle
text:
Several Mid-Market residents and businesses have sued the city of San Francisco over negligence, alleging the city facilitated an unsafe environment on the streets. 
https://t.co/x4O1wYdYei

name: sfchronicle
text: The long-anticipated live album and concert film documenting Metallica’s second collaboration with the @sfsymphony is set for release on Aug. 28. https://t.co/Z1zxfyX1ja

name: sfchronicle
text: State health officials reported an uptick in coronavirus cases among staff and residents in skilled nursing facilities: 74 health care workers and 2,318 residents at 1,223 facilities are infected. https://t.co/bvzLSK9GO9

name: sfchronicle
text:
The Giants regulars fighting injuries — Pence, Longoria and Belt — had a relatively good Friday. Manager Gabe Kapler would not rule any of them out for Thursday's season opener in Los Angeles.

https://t.co/ovO7sQMMvI

name: sfchronicle
text: “Waning antibodies affect vaccine development,” said the chief of science at S.F.’s California Academy of Sciences. “Where natural immunity doesn’t really develop or last, then vaccine programs are not likely to be easily successful or achievable.” https://t.co/yOoVoVVB7S

name: sfchronicle
text:
More than 100 inmates at Santa Rita Jail are infected with coronavirus after it spread unseen from bunk-to-bunk and cell-to-cell in the past two days, marking the jail’s largest outbreak since the pandemic began.

https://t.co/VYbnGsto6e

name: sfchronicle
text: Permanent immunity to the coronavirus may not be possible: Recent studies indicate that the human body does not retain antibodies, meaning vaccine hopes could fade. https://t.co/3QRbQcBfQF

name: sfchronicle
text:
90s cult game show "Supermarket Sweep" is now streaming on @netflix, and @hooleil talks about why it's the ultimate anti-food food show worth watching right now.

"It's kind of feminist... if you squint," she writes. https://t.co/X7QkoCkDsc

name: sfchronicle
text: BREAKING: Rep. John Lewis, a lion of the civil rights movement who went on to a long and celebrated career in Congress, has died. He was 80.  https://t.co/1X4QSFGwal

name: sfchronicle
text:
Several businesses in San Francisco have permanently closed since the Bay Area’s shelter-in-place orders began on March 17. 

Which COVID-related closure has you most upset?

https://t.co/Lk7VQVujBZ

name: sfchronicle
text:
Last month, @MickLaSalle
reviewed the documentary about Rep. John Lewis from S.F. filmmaker Dawn Porter. 

"If he sits in a cushy chair and hangs out with his cats for the rest of his life, he’ll still be remembered as a great man."

https://t.co/v7B2BTZBxa

name: sfchronicle
text: BREAKING: California DOJ will investigate the Vallejo Police Department's disposal of key evidence in the killing of Sean Monterrosa — the windshield of the unmarked police vehicle an officer shot through. https://t.co/63HLB24svy
